Probably the same people they have always been ...

The members of the Coptic Orthodox Church in the middle east.

That, at least, is the church with the oldest unbroken historical record, located still the cultural mileau most similar to the cultural mileau of first-century Palestine. So, I would guess that they are the best example of "the old fashion Christian that is talked about in the bible". And yes, they are still around today.

The Anglicans, Eastern Orthodox, and Roman Catholics also have some pretty good claims to being "the old fashion Christian that is talked about in the bible" except for the very different cultural mileus that shape their worship. They, too, are still around today and in fact, well over half of all Christians belong to these traditions and maintain their ancient ways traceable back to those first-century biblical Christians.

Are those who follow modern variations on these ancient ways -- you know: Pentacostals, Baptists, Methodists, Assemblies of God, and so on -- "*real* Christians"? *I* believe they are. Although I disagree with many of the concepts that these self-proclaimed "Christians" have merged with the historic faith, I recognize that they follow the same Master I follow. I recognize that; to the extent that they do, in my Master's name, feed the hungry, visit the prisoners, care for the widows and orphans; they too do the work of my Master's Father in Heaven and that my Master therefor calls them -- despite their heretical beliefs -- his brothers and sisters. None of us is perfect in understanding and doctrine (<g> except Anglicans, of course<g>) so it makes sense not to begrudge people the right to call themselves Christian just because I, in my imperfect understanding, disagree with them.

I have met Christian humanists and Christian witches. It's probably better for us to *listen* to them explain their own beliefs, than to presume to proclaim on their behalf what they believe. Where there are no Christian humanists or Christian witches to ask, then I guess their purported existence isn't that relevant, is it.

In the meantime, if someone wants to call himself Christian, who is has the right to stop him? No-one can say "Jesus is Lord" except by the Power of the Spirit.
